title: Mount Kinabalu
lines: You’re now looking at Mount Kinabalu, the highest peak in Southeast Asia at over 4,000 meters tall.
It’s part of Kinabalu Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site filled with thousands of plant and animal species.
For the local Kadazan-Dusun people, the mountain holds spiritual importance and is considered sacred.
Even if you’re not climbing, you can enjoy the trails, gardens and cool mountain air around the base.
When the weather’s good, the view is absolutely beautiful and you’ll want to just sit and enjoy the whole thing.

title: Kota Kinabalu Waterfront
lines: You're now at the KK Waterfront, a chilled-out spot right by the South China Sea.
This place used to be part of Kota Kinabalu’s old port but has transformed into a popular hangout spot.
You’ll find cafes, food stalls, souvenir markets and even boat rides to nearby islands.
It gets super lively in the evening, with live music and amazing sunset views.
It’s the perfect place to relax, grab a bite, and enjoy the sea breeze.

title: Mari Mari Cultural Village
lines: Welcome to Mari Mari Cultural Village,a place where you can step into Sabah’s traditional way of life.
The village is surrounded by rainforest and showcases the homes of local tribes like the Dusun, Rungus and Murut.
You can walk through their houses, try out hands-on activities and learn how things were done in the past.
There are live demos too, like cooking with bamboo, using a blowpipe and starting a fire without matches.
It’s a fun and eye-opening experience that lets you connect with Sabah’s heritage in a fun and interactive way.
